After incubation for 1 h at room temperature, cells were lysed in the presence of soybean trypsin inhibitor (0.1 g/ml), and immunoprecipitations were performed as described above. The subunits of ENaC were immunoprecipitated from metabolically labeled oocytes. Immune complexes were eluted with 30 μl of 0.2% SDS and 170 μl of IEF solubilization buffer and resolved by two-dimentional electrophoresis: first dimension, isoelectric focusing using 1% 5/7 and 4% 3/10 anpholytes (Bio-Rad); second dimension, 10% SDS-PAGE according to Ref.15Valentijn J.A. Jamieson J.D. Eur. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 76: 204-211Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar. The three subunits of ENaC are glycosylated in multiple asparagine residues: 6 in α, 10 to 12 in β, and 4 in γ. To determine the cellular compartment in which the subunits are expressed we treated the subunits of ENaC with glycanases. Endoglycosidase-H (Endo-H) cleaves N-linked oligosaccharides on high mannose and hybrids (but not complex-type) oligosaccharides making it useful for examining the maturation of the subunits as they move through the ER-Golgi compartments. As a control we usedN-glycosidase F (PNGase-F) which cleaves all types of N-glycans. Oocytes were injected with α, β, and γ subunits, metabolically labeled with a mixture of [35S]methionine and cysteine for 4 h, and immunoprecipitated with specific antibodies. The products of the immunoprecipitations were divided in three equal samples that were either left untreated or treated with glycanases and then analyzed by gel electrophoresis. Fig. 1 shows that α, β, and γ subunits were completely digested by Endo-H and PNGase-F, reducing the molecular weights to the products of in vitro translation in reticulocyte lysate. The subunits were sensitive to Endo-H when expressed singly or in combination with all three subunits indicating that they are unable to exit the ER efficiently. The results indicate that almost all the subunits of ENaC expressed in oocytes remain in pre-Golgi compartments as co-reglycosylated immature forms. Injection of cRNA of each subunit alone results in synthesis of abundant protein with half-lives (t½ ± S.E.) of 3.8 ± 0.21 h for α, 3.4 ± 0.15 h for β, and 3.9 ± 0.26 for γ (Fig. 2). These t½ values are longer than the ones previously reported in transfected cells (16Coux O. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1996; 65: 801-847Crossref PubMed Scopus (2239) Google Scholar), or in A6 cells (5May A. Puotti A. Gaeggeler H-P. Horisberger J-D. Rossier B.C. J. Am. Soc. Nephrol. 1997; 8: 1813-1822Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), and probably reflect the lower temperature at which oocytes are maintained. We also examined the t½ of β and γ subunits with deletions of the carboxyl termini because the higher current expressed by carboxyl-terminal truncated channels could be the consequence of a prolonged t½. We found that the t½ for βT was 3.0 ± 0.5 h and for γT was 3.9 ± 0.9 h, values not different from the ones observed for wild-type subunits. When αβγ or αβTγ were co-expressed thet½ values of all the subunits increased. Thet½ values of the α, β, γ, and βT subunits were 11 to 9.5 h, significantly longer than from oocytes expressing single subunits (Fig. 3). However, the t½ of β and βT were not significantly different. The kinetics of degradation were also distinct; disappearance of subunits did not follow a simple exponential function but were more linear. These observations are in agreement with the notion that assembly of subunits with the correct partners stabilizes the channel complex, whereas single subunits tend to be rapidly degraded. It is important to notice in the pulse-chase experiments in Figs. 2 and 3, that when expressed alone or in combination, the subunits remain in the co-reglycosylated, immature form. A higher molecular weight form was never seen consistent with the acquisition of complex oligosaccharides and indicative of exit from the ER. The results indicate that co-expression of α, β, and γ stabilizes the subunits in the ER preventing their rapid degradation but assembly is not enough to allow efficient exit from the ER and the appearance of a fully glycosylated mature form. To detect channels expressed at the plasma membrane, we biotinylated oocytes injected with the three subunits of ENaC using two different impermeant biotinylation reagents: EZ-link sulfo-NHS-LC-biotin (modifies lysines and arginines) and EZ-link biotin-LC-hydrazine (modifies aldehyde groups of glycoproteins generated by oxidation). In one set of experiments oocytes expressing ENaC were metabolically labeled for 36 h, and then biotinylated with EZ-link sulfo-NHS-LC-biotin. The subunits of ENaC were recovered with specific antibodies and the biotinylated fraction with streptavidin-agarose. As control for the biotinylation procedure, we injected oocytes with the α and β subunits of the Na+/K+-ATPase and looked for biotinylation of the β subunit. Fig. 4 A shows that the subunits of ENaC in the plasma membrane have higher molecular weight and migrate in broader bands than the intracellular subunits, consistent with the acquisition of complex oligosaccharides. In this experiment material from 25 oocytes was loaded on each lane, whereas for all other experiments it was the equivalent of 3 to 4 oocytes. In addition, the exposure time of the gels was five times longer to detect the biotinylated subunits. For comparison, Fig. 4 B shows the much higher intensity of the signal obtained with the β subunit of the pump. The weak signal recovered after biotinylation of ENaC could be due to low efficiency of biotinylation of the subunits in oocytes. To assess the efficiency of biotinylation of ENaC we performed a quantitative assay. GST fusion proteins used to raised the antibodies for ENaC were loaded on gels in decreasing amounts and processed for Western blotting using the corresponding affinity purified ENaC antibodies. The intensity of bands of the fusion proteins were compared with bands of Western blots obtained from biotinylated α, β, and γ subunits. Fig. 5 A shows Western blots of biotinylated α, β, and γ subunits with EZ-link sulfo-NHS-LC-biotin or EZ-link biotin-LC-hydrazine from 40 oocytes. The intensities of the bands were similar using any of the two biotinylation reagents. Fig. 5 B shows Western blots of α, β, and γ GST fusion proteins at concentrations of 50, 2.0, 0.5, and 0.1 fmol/lane. Comparison of the intensity of the biotinylated subunits with the known amount of fusion proteins in Fig. 5 Bindicates that we recovered approximately 2.0 fmol of biotinylated subunits from 40 oocytes. For contrast, Fig. 5 C shows Western blots loaded with 1/100 of the whole oocyte lysate and represents expression of both intra- and extracellular subunits. 25 oocytes from the same batch were also examined for expression of amiloride-sensitive current. The mean whole cell current was 12 ± 3.3 μA/oocyte when measured at a membrane potential of −100 mV with the two-electrode voltage clamp. Since the single channel current of ENaC in the presence of 100 mm sodium in the bath solution is 1 pA, and the mean open probability is 0.5, the number of channels at the cell surface should be close to 24 million channels/oocyte or 96 million subunits if we assume that channels are tetramers. Then, the material contained on the gel shown in Fig. 5 A corresponds to 4 × 109 subunits or 6.66 fmol. Since the intensity of the biotinylated subunits were similar to the 2.0-fmol bands of the fusion proteins, we can argue that the efficiency of biotinylation was approximately 30% and that the biotinylated subunits reflect the actual number of channels at the cell surface, only a small fraction of the total channels expressed in oocytes. This result is consistent with the values obtained by Firsov et al. (1Firsov D. Gautschi I. Merillat A-M. Rossier B.C. Schild L. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 344-352Crossref PubMed Scopus (370) Google Scholar), who used a125I-labeled anti-FLAG antibody to measure the number of channels expressed at the cell surface of oocytes. They found 0.02 fmol/μA of β and γ and 0.055 fmol/μA of α. Accordingly, for 40 oocytes that expressed a mean whole cell current of 12 μA it is expected 12 fmol at the plasma membrane. This number is very close to the value we obtained. Therefore, the channels at the plasma membrane is only a very small fraction (<1%) of the total amount of subunits expressed in oocytes. We have shown that most of the subunits remain in pre-Golgi compartments where they are eventually degraded. We examined whether the proteasomal pathway was involved in the degradation of the intracellular subunits by incubating oocytes with lactacystin, a potent and specific inhibitor of the proteasome. Proteasomal degradation is one of the major cellular pathways for removal of protein from the cytosol and from the ER (16Coux O. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1996; 65: 801-847Crossref PubMed Scopus (2239) Google Scholar). The effect of lactacystin on the t½ of β subunits expressed alone is shown in Fig. 6; degradation of β subunits was almost completely blocked. In contrast, lactacystin had less effect on the t½ when the three subunits were co-expressed (Fig. 3), indicating that assembled subunits were protected from rapid degradation by the proteasome. Despite the involvement of the proteasome in subunit degradation, we failed to detect ubiquitination in any of the subunits, even when it was sought by multiple approaches including: immunoprecipitation with anti-ubiquitin antibodies after incubation with lactacystin, or with anti-FLAG antibodies in oocytes co-injected with ENaC and ubiquitin cRNA tagged with the FLAG epitope; or co-injection with a mutant ubiquitin (ubiquitin-K48R) that inhibits polyubiquitination of proteins slowing degradation because they failed to be recognized by the proteasome (17Finley D. Sadis S. Monia B.P. Boucher P. Ecker D.J. Crooke S.T. Chau V. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 5501-5509Crossref PubMed Scopus (303) Google Scholar). We also did not detect a ladder of increasing molecular weight as it would have been expected if multiple ubiquitin moities were added (data not shown). These negative results indicate that the subunits are degraded in pre-Golgi compartments by a mechanism that involves the proteasome but does not require ubiquitination of the subunits. Two proteins with different molecular weights were frequently recovered with antibodies specific for the subunits of ENaC (Figs. 1, 2, and 6). The lower molecular weight protein is not a proteolytic product of the core glycosylated form because it is equally recognized by antibodies directed against the amino and carboxyl termini (Fig. 7), therefore, both ends of the protein are intact. The lower molecular weight protein has the same mobility as the in vitro translation product and is resistant to treatment with glycanases (Fig. 1), indicating that its lower molecular weight is due to the absence of glycosylation. It is unusual for proteins with multiple N-glycosylation sites not to be glycosylated at all because the addition of oligosaccharides occurs co-translationally in the lumen of the ER. We investigated two possibilities: (i) either the subunits are glycosylated in the ER and then are translocated back to the cytoplasm where cytosolic glycanases remove the oligosaccharides from the protein (18Suzuki T. Seko A. Kitajima K. Inoue Y. Inoue S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 17611-17618Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar); or (ii) the subunits are synthesized in the cytoplasm without incorporation into the ER membrane and without exposure to the glycosylation machinery of the ER lumen. The first mechanism has been shown to be a pathway for degradation of ER-associated proteins and is part of the quality control of the ER (19Sommer T. Wolf D. FASEB J. 1997; 11: 1227-1233Crossref PubMed Scopus (220) Google Scholar); therefore, the deglycosylated subunits could represent the fraction that is retrotranslocated from the ER to the cytosol for degradation by the proteasome. First, we demonstrated that the lower molecular weight form is indeed in the cytoplasm. Differential centrifugation of oocyte homogenates without detergent showed that it localized in the supernatant (cytosolic fraction), whereas the core-glycosylated localized in the pellet (membrane fraction) (Fig. 8). Furthermore, we examined the sensitivity of the two proteins to trypsin digestion. For that purpose, oocytes expressing βT were metabolically labeled for 4 h and then injected with trypsin. Since injected trypsin distributes in the cytoplasm of cells, only the polypeptides exposed to the cytosol can be degraded, while the ones in the ER lumen will be protected. We found that the core-glycosylated form was almost completely protected from digestion as expected for a βT subunit that only has a short amino terminus exposed to the cytoplasm. In contrast, the non-glycosylated form was completely degraded (Fig. 9).Figure 9The cytosolic form is degraded by trypsin. Metabolically labeled oocytes expressing βTwere injected with 30 nl of H2O or trypsin (25 mg/ml). After 1 h, oocytes were homogenized in the presence of soybean trypsin inhibitor (250 mg/ml) and treated for immunoprecipitation with an anti-β antibody that recognizes the domain that resides in the lumen of the ER in properly folded subunits. In cells treated with trypsin, the core-glycosylated form of βT migrates slightly faster, indicating a small change in molecular weight. In contrast, the non-glycosylated form is completely eliminated, indicating that the protein was digested by trypsin.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Next, we examined whether the cytosolic subunits were deglycosylated in the cytosol. It has been shown that the cytosol contains a PNGase-F activity that cleaves all types of asparagine boundN-glycans producing ammonia, aspartic acid in the peptide chain, and the complete oligosaccharide (24Ward C.L. Kopito R.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 25710-25718Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Accordingly, removal of all 10 to 12 N-linked oligosaccharides from the β subunit should add to the protein 10 to 12 negative charges and produce a change in isoelectric point large enough to be detected by isoelectric focusing (IEF). We resolved immunoprecipitated β subunits on two-dimensional gels and found that the higher molecular weight (ER membrane) and the lower molecular weight (cytosolic) forms both exhibited the same migration, as well as the in vitrotranslation product; therefore, the total charge in all these proteins must be the same (data not shown). We conclude that the non-glycosylated, low molecular weight protein was made in the cytoplasm and was not a product of retrotranslocation from the ER. We have shown that the limiting steps for the accumulation of functional channels in the plasma membrane are the processes of assembly and maturation of the subunits in the ER. Most of the subunits are degraded in pre-Golgi compartments where they reside in a core-glycosylated form that is sensitive to Endo-H digestion. These findings are not restricted to the oocyte expression system because previous experiments, in mammalian or amphibian cells, also showed that most of the channel protein is in the core-glycosylated form (5May A. Puotti A. Gaeggeler H-P. Horisberger J-D. Rossier B.C. J. Am. Soc. Nephrol. 1997; 8: 1813-1822Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 20Staub O. Gautschi I. Ishikawa T. Breitschopf K. Ciechanover A. Schild L. Rotin D. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 6325-6336Crossref PubMed Scopus (601) Google Scholar). The findings presented here are in sharp contrast to biosynthesis and processing of FaNaCh, a channel closely related to ENaC. In experiments similar to the ones used by us, Coscoy et al. (21Coscoy S. Lingueglia E. Lazdunski M. Barbry P. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 8317-8322Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar) showed a 74-kDa core glycosylated and a 82-kDa fully glycosylated form of FaNaCh. During the chase points, the 74-kDa polypeptide disappeared while the 82-kDa form became more intense, indicating progressive maturation of the protein and efficient delivery to the plasma membrane where was detected in large amounts (10% of the total plasma membrane proteins). Instead, we never detected maturation of ENaC into a fully glycosylated form in pulse-chase experiments, indicating that the subunits largely remain in the ER and only a very small fraction of the total protein is further processed, acquires more complex oligosaccharides, and is detected at the plasma membrane; the majority of the subunits remain inside the cell where they are degraded. Therefore, maturation and assembly of subunits seem to be important steps in the regulation of ENaC expression. When single subunits were expressed, the t½ values were short (3–4 h) and the kinetics of degradation could be fitted to a simple exponential function, indicating that they were degraded by a non-saturated pathway at a rate proportional to the amount of protein present in the cell. Degradation of the subunits expressed alone was markedly slowed by inhibition of the proteasomal activity by lactacystin, consistent with the involvement of the proteasome in the removal of unassembled subunits from the ER. Turnover of the channel proteins was different in the presence of all three subunits: the kinetics of degradation became slower, more complex, and less dependent on proteasomal activity. The results are in agreement with the notion that subunits of multimeric proteins are stabilized by association with the correct partners (22Klausner R.D. Lippincott-Schwartz J. Bonifacino J.S. Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1990; 6: 403-431Crossref PubMed Scopus (300) Google Scholar). However, despite assembly, channels left the pre-Golgi compartment in very small amounts that did not permit detection of the fully glycosylated form in the pulse-chase experiments. Although our data do not reveal the mechanisms that retain channels in the ER, the results indicate that inefficient maturation is a property intrinsic to the subunits of ENaC and it may constitute a way to limit the delivery of channels to the plasma membrane. Since ENaC is a constitutively active channel, with a relatively high open probability (P o 0.5), strict control of the number of channels at the cell surface is necessary to regulate sodium reabsorption by epithelial tissues. We found that ubiquitination does not seem to be required for the proteolysis of ENaC in the ER. Xenopus oocytes express all the machinery necessary for ubiquitination (23Nishizawa M. Okazaki K. Furuno N. Watanabe N. Sagata N. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 2433-2446Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar); indeed, we detected ubiquitinated endogenous proteins in oocytes treated with lactacystin. The failure to demonstrate ubiquitination of the ENaC subunits, even when sought by several different approaches, suggests that the subunits present in the pre-Golgi compartments are not ubiquitinated prior to degradation by the proteasome. Other membrane proteins such as CFTR are also degraded in pre-Golgi compartments but in this case ubiquitination precedes degradation (24Ward C.L. Kopito R.R. J. Biol. Cell. 1995; 83: 113-129Abstract Full Text PDF Scopus (775) Google Scholar, 26Ward C.L. Omura S. Kopito R. Cell. 1995; 83: 121-127Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1133) Google Scholar). However, ubiquitination is not obligatory to target substrates to the proteasome (27Murakami Y. Matsufuji S. Kameji T. Hayashi S. Igarashi K. Tamura T. Tanaka K. Ichihara A. Nature. 1992; 360: 597-599Crossref PubMed Scopus (669) Google Scholar, 28Yu H. Kaung G. Kobayashi S. Kopito R.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 20800-20804Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (203) Google Scholar, 29Pickart C.M. FASEB J. 1997; 11: 1055-1066Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar). Although speculative, ubiquitination may be necessary for degradation of proteins with large cytoplasmic domains such CFTR, but not for proteins with few amino acids in the cytoplasm such as the subunits of ENaC. The lack of ubiquitination in oocytes contrasts to previous reports showing ubiquitination of ENaC is transfected Hek-293 cells (20Staub O. Gautschi I. Ishikawa T. Breitschopf K. Ciechanover A. Schild L. Rotin D. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 6325-6336Crossref PubMed Scopus (601) Google Scholar). It has been postulated that Nedd4 binds to the carboxyl termini of the subunits and ubiquitinates the amino termini of α and γ (20Staub O. Gautschi I. Ishikawa T. Breitschopf K. Ciechanover A. Schild L. Rotin D. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 6325-6336Crossref PubMed Scopus (601) Google Scholar, 30Staub O. Dho S. Henry P.C. Correa J. Ishikawa T. McGlade J. Rotin D. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 2371-2380Crossref PubMed Scopus (741) Google Scholar). Ubiquitination seems to be a signal for retrieval of channels from the plasma membrane and targeting to lyzosomes for degradation. An explanation for the discrepancy may be that Nedd4 ubiquitinates channels only in the plasma membrane and not in the intracellular compartments. We have shown that in oocytes, most of the subunits are in the ER where they are degraded by a mechanism that involves the proteasome but does not require ubiquitination and is independent of binding of Nedd4. Since the fraction of channels expressed at the plasma membrane is very small and, furthermore, not all channels at the cell surface are expected to be ubiquitinated, our assays could not detect the very small number of ubiquitinated channels at the cell surface. A similar explanation may apply for the finding that wild-type and truncated subunits exhibit the same t½ values. Thet½ values calculated from pulse-chase experiments reflect the fate of the intracellular subunits and not of the small fraction present in the plasma membrane. In a previous publication (8Shimkets R.A. Lifton R.P. Canessa C.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 25537-25541Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (243) Google Scholar), we were able to measure the residence time in the plasma membrane of wild-type and carboxyl-terminal truncated channels by using an electrophysiological measurement (much more sensitive that biochemichal assays). The t½ of wild-type was 3.6 h and it was markedly prolonged for αβTγTchannels. Overexpression of subunits did not overcome the blockade of the channels in the ER nor did it increase the fraction delivered to the plasma membrane; instead, subunits appeared in the cytosol. Unassembled membrane proteins such as the MHC class I molecules (31Wiertz E.J. Tortorella D. Bogyo M., Yu J. Mothes W. Jones T.R. Rapoport T.A. Ploegh H.L. Nature. 1996; 384: 432-438Crossref PubMed Scopus (955) Google Scholar) and α chains of the T cell antigen receptor (32Huppa J.B. Ploegh H.L. Immunity. 1997; 7: 113-122Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (155) Google Scholar) are selectively released from the ER to the cytoplasm, deglycosylated, and degraded by the proteasome. We examined whether ENaC followed a similar pathway. However, we found that the cytosolic subunits were not retrotranslocated from the ER but that they were synthesized in the cytoplasm. Accumulation in the cytosol was prominent only when single subunits were expressed (Fig. 6). In oocytes producing all three subunits (Fig. 2) accumulation in the cytosol did not occur although the total amount of protein produced was approximately the same. This indicates that the phenomenon was not simply due to saturation of the translocation machinery of the ER. The results are consistent with the notion that the efficiency of translocation to the ER is influenced by the association of the several subunits with their partners and that perhaps, if the subunits cannot be assembled rapidly they remain in the translocon (33Andrews D.W. Johnson A.E. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1996; 21: 365-369Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar) for longer periods obstructing the translocation of other nascent subunits into the ER membrane. We thank Dr. M. Caplan for the cDNAs of the Na+/K+-ATPase.

Programmed cell death invariably requires the activation of proteolytic cascades that are not yet well defined but are initiated after apical caspase activation. We provide evidence that calpains and the proteasome function synergistically downstream of caspases to assist the constitutive apoptotic program of aging neutrophils, which plays an important role in resolution of inflammatory responses. Inhibitor studies indicated that “tethering” of preapoptotic senescent neutrophils to human macrophages required caspase activity. However, the development of morphological features characteristic of apoptosis, including nuclear morphology, PS exposure, surface protein shedding, and the capacity to be ingested by macrophages, required the downstream action of either calpains or the proteasome. Calpain activities were constitutively active in freshly isolated neutrophils and responsible for rearrangements in the protein composition and structure of the plasmalemmal cytoskeleton as they aged in culture and underwent apoptosis. This included a dissociation of protein(s) from F-actin, a candidate mechanism for increased susceptibility to cleavage, and a loss in immunodetectable α-actinin and ezrin, two actin-binding, membrane-anchoring proteins. These results clarify roles for different classes of proteases in a physiologically important form of constitutive apoptosis. Defining the role of calpains in apoptosis has also been confounded by the use of experimental models in which apoptosis is drug or stress induced, in which case calpain activation might occur independently of processes necessary for apoptosis.To extend our own studies on the role of calpains and eliminate the foregoing concerns, we have focused on the self-contained and constitutive apoptosis of senescent neutrophils, a physiological form of programmed cell death responsible for safe phagocytic removal of senescent neutrophils during resolution of inflammation (45Savill J. Haslett C. Semin. Cell Biol. 1995; 6: 385-393Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar, 46Savill J. Wyllie A.H. Henson J.E. Walport M.J. Henson P.M. Haslett C. J. Clin. We report herein that calpains are involved in neutrophil apoptosis and that one of their functions is to modify the composition and association of actin-binding proteins with F-actin at the plasma membrane.DISCUSSIONWith the exception of the caspase family (2Martin S.J. Green D.R. Cell. 1995; 82: 349-352Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1258) Google Scholar, 4Earnshaw W.C. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1995; 7: 337-343Crossref PubMed Scopus (509) Google Scholar, 5Alnemri E.S. J. Cell. Biochem. 1997; 64: 33-42Crossref PubMed Scopus (288) Google Scholar), the role and importance of intracellular proteases in apoptosis remain poorly defined and often controversial. Insofar as any result with protease inhibitors must be interpreted with caution, we have found evidence that caspases (zVAD), calpains (calpeptin and ALLN), and the proteasome (lactacystin and ALLN) all play a role in the constitutive apoptosis of neutrophils in vitro. The interplay between these proteases, however, was not simple. Indeed, our results demonstrate that in aging neutrophils a high degree of synergy existed between calpains and the proteasome, which acted downstream of caspases, to effect the constitutive apoptotic program of neutrophils.First we showed that calpains were constitutively active in freshly isolated neutrophils as assessed by the in situ hydrolysis of a synthetic calpain substrate, although we could not exclude the possibility that the conditions for substrate cell loading were responsible for its activation. This activity, nevertheless, was blocked with the cell-permeable inhibitors calpeptin and, to a lesser extent, ALLN. However, only ALLN, not calpeptin, was able to inhibit the constitutive apoptosis of senescent neutrophils over a 24-h period of culture. When we used lactacystin, at concentrations known to be effective for the inhibition of the proteasomal complex and an alternative target of ALLN action, we found no evidence that any aspect of neutrophil apoptosis or viability was affected. This raised the intriguing possibility that the inhibitory effect of ALLN on morphological apoptosis was attributable to the combined inhibition of calpains and the proteasome. Indeed, the combined effect of lactacystin and calpeptin in suppressing neutrophil apoptosis provided compelling evidence that a high degree of synergy existed between calpain and proteasomal activities. That ALLN was not as effective as the combination of lactacystin and calpeptin was curious but again may implicate other targets of ALLN action that may have been proapoptotic (58Zhu W. Murtha P.E. Young C.Y.F. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Comm. 1995; 214: 1130-1137Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar).Throughout these studies we were unable to dissociate nuclear morphological events from cell surface phenomena such as PS exposure or CD16 and CD43 protein shedding. This confirmed that nuclear morphology and surface changes characteristic of apoptosis were coordinately regulated and distal within the apoptotic program (Fig. 7). This contrasts with the recognition, but not ingestion, of aged neutrophils by Mφ cells, in which an inhibition of both calpains and the proteasome did not inhibit the ability of Mφ cells to bind aged neutrophils. Given that the tethering of neutrophils was sensitive to caspase inhibition, this suggests that Mφ recognition was proximal to caspases but upstream of calpain and proteasomal activities required to complete the apoptotic program. These results support the likelihood that phagocyte uptake of apoptotic (59Savill J. Nature. 1998; 392: 442-443Crossref PubMed Scopus (207) Google Scholar) or damaged (60Sambrano G.R. Terpstra V. Steinberg D. Arterioscler. Thromb. Vasc. Biol. 1997; 17: 3442-3448Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar) cells involves potentially distinguishable stages of binding to the phagocyte followed by a separate ingestion phase.The current data establish that calpains are present in neutrophils and that their inhibition, in conjunction with that of the proteasome, results in a significant suppression of constitutive neutrophil apoptosis. However, the data provide no indication as to how calpains, or for that matter the proteasome, can effect this inhibition. Nevertheless, although calpain activity was apparently diminished once neutrophils had undergone apoptosis, this was shown to be responsible for a number of phenomena associated with the apoptotic phenotype. Furthermore, possible roles for calpain and the proteasome were suggested by the ability of both calpeptin and ALLN to wholly inhibit the immunodetection of an epitope within the immediate N terminus of β-actin that became unmasked as neutrophils underwent apoptosis, and each inhibitor impaired the loss and degradation of α-actinin and ezrin, two actin-binding, membrane-anchoring proteins. Because the anti-actin mAb used in these studies recognized an epitope adjacent to a previously characterized site of cleavage within F-actin, it may be speculated that exposure of the AC-15 epitope in the N terminus of actin and degradation of α-actinin and ezrin may be linked. Furthermore, the scissile site was previously found to be devoid of a consensus site for caspase cleavage, and ALLN, not zVAD, was able to inhibit this cleavage (12Brown S.B. Bailey K. Savill J. Biochem. J. 1997; 323: 233-237Crossref PubMed Scopus (131) Google Scholar), a finding we have since validated with the use of calpeptin (data not presented).Taken together, these results suggest that calpains are responsible for the dissociation of actin-binding proteins, including α-actinin and ezrin, from filamentous β-actin. This results in the unmasking of an immediate N-terminal epitope recognized by the mAb AC-15, rendering it susceptible to subsequent proteolysis. It is tempting to speculate further that the breakdown in cytoskeletal protein associations at the plasmalemmal interface direct the shedding of l-selectin, which binds α-actinin, and CD43, which binds ezrin. Recently, ezrin was shown to first dephosphorylate and then translocate, without degradation, from the plasma membrane to the cytoplasm after Fas-induced death in L cells (61Kondo T. Takeuchi K. Doi Y. Yonemura S. Nagata S. Tsukita S. Tsukita S. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 139: 749-758Crossref PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar).In conclusion, we have presented evidence that calpains and the proteasome function synergistically to complete the constitutive apoptotic program of senescent neutrophils, a physiological form of cell death important in resolution of inflammation. Most importantly, these two proteolytic activities appear to function downstream of caspases in mutually redundant pathways where the loss of both activities inhibits the characteristic phenotypic changes seen in apoptosis. This is supported, and not excluded, by recent reports in which both the calpains and the proteasome were separately implicated as key effectors of thymocyte apoptosis. In the absence of combined inhibitor studies and a wider range of criteria to assess apoptosis, other than DNA fragmentation and nuclear morphology, it remains a distinct possibility that thymocytes also require synergy between calpain and proteasomal activities. Proteases are increasingly recognized as playing a key role in effecting apoptosis and its associated morphology in cells destined to die programmed deaths (1Kumar S. Harvey N.L. Cohen J.J. Cell Death Differ. 1996; 3: 275-283PubMed Google Scholar, 4Earnshaw W.C. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1995; 7: 337-343Crossref PubMed Scopus (509) Google Scholar). It is because of these outcomes of calpain action, which have much in common with aspects of apoptosis, i.e.calcium fluxes and the disassembly of the cytoskeleton, that calpains are often postulated to have a role in apoptosis. But whether calpain activity is proximal, as has been suggested, or distal to initiation of the apoptotic process remains unclear. Defining the role of calpains in apoptosis has also been confounded by the use of experimental models in which apoptosis is drug or stress induced, in which case calpain activation might occur independently of processes necessary for apoptosis. To extend our own studies on the role of calpains and eliminate the foregoing concerns, we have focused on the self-contained and constitutive apoptosis of senescent neutrophils, a physiological form of programmed cell death responsible for safe phagocytic removal of senescent neutrophils during resolution of inflammation (45Savill J. Haslett C. Semin. Cell Biol. 1995; 6: 385-393Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar, 46Savill J. Wyllie A.H. Henson J.E. Walport M.J. Henson P.M. Haslett C. J. Clin. We report herein that calpains are involved in neutrophil apoptosis and that one of their functions is to modify the composition and association of actin-binding proteins with F-actin at the plasma membrane. DISCUSSIONWith the exception of the caspase family (2Martin S.J. Green D.R. Cell. 1995; 82: 349-352Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1258) Google Scholar, 4Earnshaw W.C. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1995; 7: 337-343Crossref PubMed Scopus (509) Google Scholar, 5Alnemri E.S. J. Cell. Biochem. 1997; 64: 33-42Crossref PubMed Scopus (288) Google Scholar), the role and importance of intracellular proteases in apoptosis remain poorly defined and often controversial. Insofar as any result with protease inhibitors must be interpreted with caution, we have found evidence that caspases (zVAD), calpains (calpeptin and ALLN), and the proteasome (lactacystin and ALLN) all play a role in the constitutive apoptosis of neutrophils in vitro. The interplay between these proteases, however, was not simple. Indeed, our results demonstrate that in aging neutrophils a high degree of synergy existed between calpains and the proteasome, which acted downstream of caspases, to effect the constitutive apoptotic program of neutrophils.First we showed that calpains were constitutively active in freshly isolated neutrophils as assessed by the in situ hydrolysis of a synthetic calpain substrate, although we could not exclude the possibility that the conditions for substrate cell loading were responsible for its activation. This activity, nevertheless, was blocked with the cell-permeable inhibitors calpeptin and, to a lesser extent, ALLN. However, only ALLN, not calpeptin, was able to inhibit the constitutive apoptosis of senescent neutrophils over a 24-h period of culture. When we used lactacystin, at concentrations known to be effective for the inhibition of the proteasomal complex and an alternative target of ALLN action, we found no evidence that any aspect of neutrophil apoptosis or viability was affected. This raised the intriguing possibility that the inhibitory effect of ALLN on morphological apoptosis was attributable to the combined inhibition of calpains and the proteasome. Indeed, the combined effect of lactacystin and calpeptin in suppressing neutrophil apoptosis provided compelling evidence that a high degree of synergy existed between calpain and proteasomal activities. That ALLN was not as effective as the combination of lactacystin and calpeptin was curious but again may implicate other targets of ALLN action that may have been proapoptotic (58Zhu W. Murtha P.E. Young C.Y.F. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Comm. 1995; 214: 1130-1137Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar).Throughout these studies we were unable to dissociate nuclear morphological events from cell surface phenomena such as PS exposure or CD16 and CD43 protein shedding. This confirmed that nuclear morphology and surface changes characteristic of apoptosis were coordinately regulated and distal within the apoptotic program (Fig. 7). This contrasts with the recognition, but not ingestion, of aged neutrophils by Mφ cells, in which an inhibition of both calpains and the proteasome did not inhibit the ability of Mφ cells to bind aged neutrophils. Given that the tethering of neutrophils was sensitive to caspase inhibition, this suggests that Mφ recognition was proximal to caspases but upstream of calpain and proteasomal activities required to complete the apoptotic program. These results support the likelihood that phagocyte uptake of apoptotic (59Savill J. Nature. 1998; 392: 442-443Crossref PubMed Scopus (207) Google Scholar) or damaged (60Sambrano G.R. Terpstra V. Steinberg D. Arterioscler. Thromb. Vasc. Biol. 1997; 17: 3442-3448Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar) cells involves potentially distinguishable stages of binding to the phagocyte followed by a separate ingestion phase.The current data establish that calpains are present in neutrophils and that their inhibition, in conjunction with that of the proteasome, results in a significant suppression of constitutive neutrophil apoptosis. However, the data provide no indication as to how calpains, or for that matter the proteasome, can effect this inhibition. Nevertheless, although calpain activity was apparently diminished once neutrophils had undergone apoptosis, this was shown to be responsible for a number of phenomena associated with the apoptotic phenotype. Furthermore, possible roles for calpain and the proteasome were suggested by the ability of both calpeptin and ALLN to wholly inhibit the immunodetection of an epitope within the immediate N terminus of β-actin that became unmasked as neutrophils underwent apoptosis, and each inhibitor impaired the loss and degradation of α-actinin and ezrin, two actin-binding, membrane-anchoring proteins. Because the anti-actin mAb used in these studies recognized an epitope adjacent to a previously characterized site of cleavage within F-actin, it may be speculated that exposure of the AC-15 epitope in the N terminus of actin and degradation of α-actinin and ezrin may be linked. Furthermore, the scissile site was previously found to be devoid of a consensus site for caspase cleavage, and ALLN, not zVAD, was able to inhibit this cleavage (12Brown S.B. Bailey K. Savill J. Biochem. J. 1997; 323: 233-237Crossref PubMed Scopus (131) Google Scholar), a finding we have since validated with the use of calpeptin (data not presented).Taken together, these results suggest that calpains are responsible for the dissociation of actin-binding proteins, including α-actinin and ezrin, from filamentous β-actin. This results in the unmasking of an immediate N-terminal epitope recognized by the mAb AC-15, rendering it susceptible to subsequent proteolysis. It is tempting to speculate further that the breakdown in cytoskeletal protein associations at the plasmalemmal interface direct the shedding of l-selectin, which binds α-actinin, and CD43, which binds ezrin. Recently, ezrin was shown to first dephosphorylate and then translocate, without degradation, from the plasma membrane to the cytoplasm after Fas-induced death in L cells (61Kondo T. Takeuchi K. Doi Y. Yonemura S. Nagata S. Tsukita S. Tsukita S. J. We investigated the interaction dynamics of human abasic endonuclease, the Ape1 protein (also called Ref1, Hap1, or Apex), with its DNA substrate and incised product using electrophoretic assays and site-specific amino acid substitutions. Changing aspartate 283 to alanine (D283A) left 10% residual activity, contrary to a previous report, but complementation of repair-deficient bacteria by the D283A Ape1 protein was consistent with its activity in vitro. The D308A, D283/D308A double mutant, and histidine 309 to asparagine proteins had 22, 1, and ∼0.02% of wild-type Ape1 activity, respectively. Despite this range of enzymatic activities, all the mutant proteins had near-wild-type binding affinity specific for DNA containing a synthetic abasic site. Thus, substrate recognition and cleavage are genetically separable steps. Both the wild-type and mutant Ape1 proteins bound strongly to the enzyme incision product, an incised abasic site, which suggested that Ape1 might exhibit product inhibition. The use of human DNA polymerase β to increase Ape1 activity by eliminating the incision product supports this conclusion. Notably, the complexes of the D283A, D308A, and D283A/D308A double mutant proteins with both intact and incised abasic DNA were significantly more stable than complexes containing wild-type Ape1, which may contribute to the lower turnover numbers of the mutant enzymes. Wild-type Ape1 protein bound tightly to DNA containing a one-nucleotide gap but not to DNA with a nick, consistent with the proposal that substrate recognition by Ape1 involves a space bracketed by duplex DNA, rather than mere flexibility of the DNA. Wild-type Ape1 protein bound tightly to DNA containing a one-nucleotide gap but not to DNA with a nick, consistent with the proposal that substrate recognition by Ape1 involves a space bracketed by duplex DNA, rather than mere flexibility of the DNA. apurinic/apyrimidinic tetrahydrofuran 51-mer double-strand DNA containing a tetrahydrofuran residue at position 22 electrophoretic-mobility-shift assay DNA polymerase β polymerase chain reaction methyl methanesulfonate bovine serum albumin polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. Base excision repair (1Seeberg E. Eide L. Bjorås M. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1995; 20: 391-397Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (472) Google Scholar, 2Wilson S.H. Mutat. Res. 1998; 407: 203-215Crossref PubMed Scopus (265) Google Scholar) is a multistep process that corrects a diverse array of spontaneous and mutagen-induced DNA lesions. The process can be initiated by DNA glycosylases, which excise damaged bases to create apurinic/apyrimidinic (AP)1 sites. Modified abasic sites can arise directly from oxidative DNA-damaging agents, such as ionizing radiation (3von Sonntag C. The Chemical Basis of Radiation Biology. Taylor and Francis, London1987Google Scholar). The AP and modified abasic sites are substrates for class II AP endonucleases, which cleave the 5′ phosphodiester of both regular (hydrolytic) AP sites (4Demple B. Harrison L. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1994; 63: 915-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (1300) Google Scholar) and oxidized abasic residues (5Xu, Y.-J., Kim, E. Y., and Demple, B. (1998) J. Biol. Chem. 273, in pressGoogle Scholar). Excision of the lesion, DNA repair synthesis, and ligation complete the process (1Seeberg E. Eide L. Bjorås M. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1995; 20: 391-397Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (472) Google Scholar, 2Wilson S.H. Mutat. Res. 1998; 407: 203-215Crossref PubMed Scopus (265) Google Scholar). Ape1 protein is quantitatively the main AP endonuclease of human cells (6Chen D.S. Herman T. Demple B. Nucleic Acids Res. 1991; 19: 5907-5914Crossref PubMed Scopus (230) Google Scholar, 7Demple B. Herman T. Chen D.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 11450-11454Crossref PubMed Scopus (478) Google Scholar). This DNA repair protein was independently named Hap1 (8Robson C.N. Hickson I.D. Nucleic Acids Res. 1991; 19: 5519-5523Crossref PubMed Scopus (293) Google Scholar) and Apex (9Seki S. Hatsushika M. Watanabe S. Akiyama K. Nagao K. Tsutsui K. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1992; 1131: 287-299Crossref PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar), and as an in vitro activator of DNA binding activity for some oxidized transcription factors, it was also named Ref1 (10Xanthoudakis S. Miao G.G. Curran T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 23-27Crossref PubMed Scopus (320) Google Scholar, 11Xanthoudakis S. Miao G. Wang F. Pan Y.C. Curran T. A. 1994; 91: 23-27Crossref PubMed Scopus (320) Google Scholar, 12Walker L.J. Robson C.N. Black E. Gillespie D. Hickson I.D. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 5370-5376Crossref PubMed Scopus (264) Google Scholar) and the C-terminal domain contains the AP endonuclease activity within a 280-residue polypeptide sequence (10Xanthoudakis S. Miao G.G. Curran T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 23-27Crossref PubMed Scopus (320) Google Scholar,12Walker L.J. Robson C.N. Black E. Gillespie D. Hickson I.D. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 5370-5376Crossref PubMed Scopus (264) Google Scholar, 13Izumi T. Mitra S. Carcinogenesis. 1998; 19: 525-527Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar) homologous to exonuclease III of Escherichia coli(27% identity), the ExoA protein of Streptococcus pneumoniae (39% identity), the Rrp1 protein of Drosophila melanogaster (50% identity), and the Arp protein of Arabidopsis thaliana (57% identity) (4Demple B. Harrison L. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1994; 63: 915-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (1300) Google Scholar, 14Barzilay G. Hickson I.D. BioEssays. 1995; 17: 713-719Crossref PubMed Scopus (198) Google Scholar). The proteins of the Ape1/exonuclease III family exhibit a range of enzymatic activities on duplex DNA. Along with the class II AP endonuclease activity, exonuclease III possesses duplex-specific 3′-5′ exonuclease activity, 3′-repair phosphodiesterase activity, 3′-phosphatase activity, and RNase H activity (15Richardson C. Kornberg A. J. Biol. Chem. 1964; 239: 242-250Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 16Richardson C. Lehman I. Kornberg A. J. Biol. Chem. 1964; 239: 251-258Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 17Demple B. Johnson A. Fung D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1986; 83: 7731-7735Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar, 18Bernelot-Moens C. Demple B. Nucleic Acids Res. 1989; 17: 587-600Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). Ape1 protein also has these multiple activities, but with 3′-repair diesterase, 3′-phosphatase, RNase H, and exonuclease activities 100–10,000-fold lower than its AP endonuclease activity (4Demple B. Harrison L. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1994; 63: 915-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (1300) Google Scholar, 19Wilson III, D.M. Takeshita M. Grollman A.P. Demple B. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 16002-16007Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar, 20Barzilay G. Walker L.J. Robson C.N. Hickson I.D. Nucleic Acids Res. 1995; 23: 1544-1550Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar, 21Suh D. Wilson III, D.M. Povirk L.F. Nucleic Acids Res. 1997; 25: 2495-2500Crossref PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar). The presence of multiple catalytic functions for exonuclease III, a relatively small (M r ∼30,000), monomeric protein suggested that a single active site catalyzes all the enzymatic reactions (22Weiss B. J. Biol. Chem. 1976; 251: 1896-1901Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In that model, distinct recognition elements in the protein were proposed to interact with duplex DNA 5′ to the target site, and a “space” in the DNA duplex caused by a missing base or frayed 3′-end. The crystal structure of exonuclease III has been solved, and a catalytic mechanism was proposed involving a single active site (23Mol C.D. Kuo C.F. Thayer M.M. Cunningham R.P. Tainer J.A. Nature. 1995; 374: 381-386Crossref PubMed Scopus (343) Google Scholar). The recently proposed crystal structure of Ape1/Hap1 protein (24Gorman M.A. Morera S. Rothwell D.G. de La Fortelle E. Mol C.D. Tainer J.A. Hickson I.D. Freemont P.S. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 6548-6558Crossref PubMed Scopus (289) Google Scholar) prompted an essentially identical proposal that involves a single active site for this enzyme. Both models involve amino acid residues that are conserved in the Ape1/exonuclease III family, and the properties of some site-specific mutant Ape1 proteins are consistent with the proposal (25Barzilay G. Mol C.D. Robson C.N. Walker L.J. Cunningham R.P. Tainer J.A. Hickson I.D. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1995; 2: 561-568Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar, 26Rothwell D.G. Hickson I.D. Nucleic Acids Res. 1996; 24: 4217-4221Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). In a reverse approach, Gu et al.(27Gu L. Huang S.M. Sander M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 32685-32692Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) used an in vivo complementation assay to isolate mutants of the Drosophila Rrp1 protein with altered repair capacity or specificity. Some of the alterations in these proteins were mapped to conserved residues that do not correspond to functional residues proposed for exonuclease III or Ape1. One of the Rrp1 mutant proteins had diminished 3′-repair diesterase activity but normal AP endonuclease activity. Thus, either these proteins have more than one active site, or substrate specificity can be modulated independently of the catalytic activity. We have previously addressed the mechanism of substrate recognition by Ape1 protein using electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA) and footprinting methods (28Wilson III, D.M. Takeshita M. Demple B. Nucleic Acids Res. 1997; 25: 933-939Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). Those studies showed that Ape1 binds specifically around the abasic site in DNA and causes a pronounced distortion at the abasic site in a preincision complex (19Wilson III, D.M. Takeshita M. Grollman A.P. Demple B. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 16002-16007Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar). However, the EMSA conditions and those of others (26Rothwell D.G. Hickson I.D. Nucleic Acids Res. 1996; 24: 4217-4221Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar, 29Strauss P.R. Beard W.A. Patterson T.A. Wilson S.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 1302-1307Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (141) Google Scholar) were not suitable for biochemical characterization, because the protein-DNA complexes were relatively unstable. Here we report improved conditions for EMSA and use the assay to monitor Ape1 binding and dissociation from an abasic substrate and the incised product. We have examined the interactions for several site-specific mutant forms of Ape1. We show here that Ape1 has a high affinity to the incised product DNA and to DNA with a one-nucleotide gap, and the several mutations that affect the catalytic activity to different degrees do not significantly affect abasic site recognition but do affect the dynamics of the protein-DNA interaction. Methods Enzymol. 1995; 262: 507-521Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). Cell lysates (fraction I) were prepared as described by Hupp and Kaguni (41Hupp T.R. Kaguni J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 13128-13136Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The proteins were resuspended in Buffer A (50 mm HEPES-KOH (pH 7.5), 1 mm EDTA, 0.1 mm dithiothreitol, 10% (v/v) glycerol) containing 100 mm KCl and dialyzed against the same buffer (fraction II). Fraction II was applied to a 20-ml phosphocellulose (Whatman P11) column and then eluted with a linear gradient of 100–750 mm KCl in Buffer A. The peak fractions containing Ape1 were pooled and dialyzed against Buffer A containing 100 mm KCl, (fraction III). The peak fractions containing Ape1 were pooled and concentrated by dialysis against Buffer A containing 200 mm KCl and 20% polyethylene glycol (average molecular weight, 8000) (fraction IV). Kaguni J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 13128-13136Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The electrophoresis buffer contained 6 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.8), 5 mmsodium acetate, and 0.1 mm EDTA (43Ng J.Y. Marians K.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 15642-15648Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar), and the gels were subjected to a constant voltage of 8 V/cm applied for 2 h at 4 °C. Following gel electrophoresis, the gels were dried and autoradiographed at –80 °C. The amount of DNA present in each band was quantified using a Molecular Imager system (Bio-Rad). To follow dissociation, binding reaction mixtures (100 μl) containing 1 nm 51F DNA and 7.8 nm Ape1 protein were incubated on ice for 10 min. The subsequent steps were carried out at 0–4 °C using equipment prechilled to 4 °C. At time 0, 10-μl samples were removed, mixed with 1 μl of a 1-μmunlabeled 51F stock, and incubated for various times on ice before being loaded on a prerunning gel to separate free DNA from the Ape1-DNA complexes. To deplete the Ape1 reaction product from the reaction mixture, we used human Polβ and a 51-mer oligonucleotide (100 nm) containing a natural AP site as the substrate. The concentration of proteins used is indicated in the figure legends. After the incision reactions, the AP site was treated with NaBH4 (140 mm) to reduce and stabilize it against spontaneous β-elimination (45Matsumoto Y. Kim K. Science. 1995; 269: 699-702Crossref PubMed Scopus (650) Google Scholar). After inactivation of the enzymes by heating at 80 °C for 1 min, the DNA was analyzed on a 20% polyacrylamide gel containing 8 m urea. The amount of DNA present in each band was quantified using a Molecular Imager system (Bio-Rad). To monitor AP endonuclease activity during purification, poly[d(A-T)] containing [α-32P,uracil-3H]dUMP was used as a substrate. Just before use, the polymer was treated with uracil-DNA glycosylase (kindly provided by Dr. Dale Mosbaugh, Oregon State University) at 37 °C for 1.5 h under standard assay conditions. The AP endonuclease assays contained DNA with 1.8 pmol of AP sites in 25 μl, and the reactions were initiated by addition of an enzyme sample (≤2 μl), followed by incubation at 37 °C for 5 min. The reactions were stopped by addition of 25 μl of stop solution (0.45n NaOH, 25 mm EDTA) and heating for 45 min at 65 °C. The amount of incised AP sites was determined as the acid-soluble, Norit-nonadsorbed radioactivity following treatment at alkaline pH; β-elimination of nonincised AP sites does not liberate the 32P label in Norit-nonadsorbable form (34Levin J.D. Demple B. Nucleic Acids Res. 1990; 18: 5069-5075Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). One unit of AP endonuclease was defined as the amount of activity that cleaves 1 pmol of AP sites per min. A. 1987; 84: 4389-4392Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar) was used as a substrate. Assays contained 50 pmol of substrate DNA in buffer, 25 μl of 50 mm HEPES-KOH (pH 7.5), 50 mm KCl, 0.1 mg/ml BSA, 10 mm MgCl2, 0.5 mmdithiothreitol, and 100 μm each of [α-32P]dTTP, dGTP, dCTP, and dATP and were initiated by the addition of an enzyme sample (≤2 μl) and incubation at 37 °C for 5 min. The reactions were stopped by addition of 25 μl of 50 mm EDTA, and 5-μl samples were spotted on DE81 paper (Whatman), which was washed three times with 0.5 mNa2HPO4. The amount of incorporated dTMP was determined as the radioactivity retained on the paper (38Sambrook J. Fritsch E.F. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. 2nd Ed. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989Google Scholar). The site-specifically mutated Ape1 proteins were purified following overexpression in E. coli strain BL21 (DE3). After induction of the D283A and D308A mutant proteins, the crude extracts (fraction I) containing these proteins displayed significantly higher AP endonuclease activity than extracts of the control strain (data not shown), which indicated that both the D283A and D308A proteins retain substantial enzymatic activity. This result seemed to contrast with the data of Barzilayet al. (25Barzilay G. Mol C.D. Robson C.N. Walker L.J. Cunningham R.P. Tainer J.A. Hickson I.D. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1995; 2: 561-568Crossref PubMed Scopus (121) Google Scholar), who reported a D283A mutant protein that had ∼2000-fold reduced activity. Therefore, we purified the mutant proteins very carefully, and both the AP endonuclease activity and the amount of the induced M r 37,000 protein were monitored during all purification steps. In contrast to the above, for the D283A/D308A double-mutant and H309N proteins, no increase was detected in the total AP endonuclease activity in crude extracts of cells after protein induction, even though substantial amounts of the induced recombinant proteins were detected by SDS-PAGE (data not shown). Thus, only the inducedM r 37,000 protein could be monitored during the purification of the D283A/D308A and H309N proteins. In the final step of the H309N purification, the leading edge of a bacterial AP endonuclease peak introduced <5% contaminating activity (data not shown). Analysis of these preparations by SDS-PAGE and staining with Coomassie Brilliant Blue (Fig. 1) or silver (data not shown) indicated that they contained only a single predominant polypeptide (≥95%) with M r ∼37,000 as expected for this protein of 35,500 Da (7Demple B. Herman T. Chen D.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 11450-11454Crossref PubMed Scopus (478) Google Scholar). Interestingly, the two proteins containing the D283A mutation migrated slightly faster in the gel. Osteocalcin gene expression is initiated perinatally and is restricted to mature osteoblasts and odontoblasts. Because their pattern of expression is highly restricted, the osteocalcin genes are excellent tools to study osteoblast-specific gene expression. To define the mechanisms of osteocalcin cell-specific gene expression in vivo, we generated transgenic mice harboring deletion mutants of the promoter region of OG2, one of the mouse osteocalcin genes. We show here that only 647 base pairs of this promoter are sufficient to confer cell-specific and time-specific expression to a reporter gene in vivo. This promoter fragment contains two copies of OSE2. This osteoblast-specificcis-acting element binds Osf2, a recently characterized osteoblast-specific transcription factor (Ducy, P., Zhang, R., Geoffroy, V., Ridall, A. L., and Karsenty, G. (1997)Cell 89, 747–754). We also demonstrate that the proximal OSE2 element is critical to confer an osteoblast-specific, developmentally regulated pattern of expression to a reporter gene. The other OSE2 element, located more upstream and presenting a lower affinity for Osf2, affects only weakly OG2 promoter activity. These data demonstrate the crucial role of Osf2 in controlling osteocalcin gene expression. Since osteocalcin synthesis is a hallmark of the differentiated osteoblast phenotype, these results suggest that, beyond its developmental function, Osf2 is also required for the maintenance of the osteoblast phenotype postnatally.

The expression of the β-amyloid precursor protein (APP), which plays a key role in the development of Alzheimer's disease, is regulated by a variety of cellular mediators in a cell-dependent manner. In the present study, we present evidence that thyroid hormones negatively regulate the expression of the APP gene in neuroblastoma cells. Transient transfection studies using plasmids that contain progressive deletions of the 5′ region of the gene demonstrate that triiodothyronine (T3), the more active form of the thyroid hormones, represses APP promoter activity by a mechanism that requires binding of the nuclear T3 receptor (TR) to a specific sequence located in the first exon. The unliganded receptor increases promoter activity, and T3 reverses that activity to basal levels. The repressive effect of T3 does not exhibit TR isoform specificity, and it is equally mediated by TRα and TRβ. Gel mobility shift assays using in vitro synthesized nuclear receptors and nuclear extracts led to the identification of a negative thyroid hormone response element, at nucleotide position +80/+96, that preferentially binds heterodimers of TR with the retinoid X receptor. Insertion of sequences containing this element confers negative regulation by T3 to a heterologous TK promoter, thus indicating the functionality of the element. In the present study, we present evidence that thyroid hormones negatively regulate the expression of the APP gene in neuroblastoma cells. The repressive effect of T3 does not exhibit TR isoform specificity, and it is equally mediated by TRα and TRβ.
