Chem. 1997; 272: 16343-16350Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar). We report here small angle x-ray scattering and neutron contrast variation measurements on the PKA holoenzyme (R2C2) and a Δ1–91RC heterodimer, each reconstituted with partially deuterated R and protiated C subunits. The different neutron scattering properties of hydrogen (protium) and deuterium enable us to extract the structural parameters for the C and R subunits within the complexes. From these measurements, we have determined the molecular boundaries of the RC dimer, the PKA holoenzyme, and the subunits within each complex. Using these data, we have derived a low resolution model for each PKA form. Our data for C and the in tandem cAMP-binding sites of R are consistent with the molecular dimensions of their respective crystal structures and allow for an assignment of their spatial alignment, thereby giving insights into the nature of the R-C interaction. We also report scattering studies of the individual C and R subunits that enable us to address whether the catalytic cleft in the C subunit is open or closed when C interacts with R and the extent of the cAMP-induced conformational change in R. Initial experiments suggested that the optimum preparation of a chimeric deuterated-protiated PKA holoenzyme was achieved using myristoylated catalytic subunit isolated directly from bovine heart and bacterially expressed deuterated regulatory subunit. Bacterially expressed nonmyristoylated C was not used because of the potential for the myristoyl group to play a role in the structure of the protein that is important for its interactions with R. Bovine heart Cα was prepared and purified to homogeneity as described previously (26Fletcher W.H. Van Patten S.M. Cheng H.-C. Walsh D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 5504-5513Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Deuterated RIIα was prepared by expression procedures similar to those used previously for the preparation of other deuterated proteins (27Olah G.A. Rokop S. Wang A.C. Blechner S.L. Trewhella J. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 8233-8239Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 28Krueger J.K. Olah G.A. Rokop S.E. Zhi G. Stull J.T. Trewhella J. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 6017-6023Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). In brief, the murine RIIα vector (PET11D), provided by Dr. John Scott (29Scott J.D. Glaccum M.B. Zoller M.J. Uhler M.D. Helfman D.M. McKnight G.S. Krebs E.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 5186-5192Google Scholar), was expressed in E. coliBL21DE3 in a mixture of D2O and H2O containing deuterated algal hydrolysate diluted with nondeuterated amino acids and glucose to give the average levels of deuteration desired (27Olah G.A. Rokop S. Wang A.C. Blechner S.L. Trewhella J. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 8233-8239Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The bacteria were adapted from growth in LB/carbenicillin (50 μg/ml) to growth in the deuterated algal hydrolysate over a period of 3 days by diluting and growing mid-log phase cells (2% innoculum) in LB, to LB in D2O (55–65%), and then to the final deuterated medium. Production of the RIIα was induced by the addition of isopropyl-β-d-thiogalactopyranoside to the medium at a final concentration of 1 mm when the absorbance of the culture (A 600) was 0.6–0.8, and the culture continued for 16 h at 27 °C. Following lysis in 50 mm MES, 150 mm NaCl, 15 mm2-mecaptoethanol, 1.0 μm leupeptin, 1.0 μmpepstatin, 50 μm 4-(2-aminoethyl)-benzenesulfonyl fluoride, 5.0 mm benzamidine, pH 6.8, the R subunit was purified by cAMP-agarose (N6 attachment, 11-atom spacer) affinity chromatography (10-ml bed volume/liter of original culture volume) with elution and dialysis conditions based upon those established for the R subunit purification from bovine heart (26Fletcher W.H. Van Patten S.M. Cheng H.-C. Walsh D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 5504-5513Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). At this stage of preparation, R was about 95% pure and was obtained in yields of 11–17 mg/liter of original culture. Holoenzyme was formed by incubation of deuterated R with a 20% excess of bovine heart C on ice for 2 h, at protein concentrations of 0.4–0.8 mg/ml of each subunit. The reconstituted holoenzyme was then purified by Q2 anion exchange (Bio-Rad™) FPLC chromatography with an NaCl gradient elution. The final preparation was >99% pure by SDS gel electrophoresis, and it exhibited a specific activity of 9.2 μmol of 32P incorporated/min/mg of protein in a Kemptide protein kinase assay plus cAMP, a without/with cAMP activity ratio of 0.02, aK a cAMP = 0.04 μm, and a molecular mass of 280 kDa by gel filtration and of 162 kDa by native gel electrophoresis according to the method of Hedrick and Smith (30Hedrick J.L. Smith A.J. Arch. Biochem. Biophys. 1968; 26: 155-164Crossref Scopus (1488) Google Scholar). These characteristics are the same as those of fully protiated PKA holoenzyme. Δ1–91RIIwas obtained by limited proteolysis using 5.0 mg of the 95% pure deuterated RIIα with chymotrypsin-agarose beads (0.5 units/mg of RIIα) at 2 °C for 30 min in a volume of 5 ml in 5 mm MES, 150 mm NaCl, 15 mm2-mercaptoethanol, pH 6.8. After 30 min on ice, the solution was cleared of chymotrypsin activity by centrifugation (twice) at 4 °C in a microcentrifuge. At this stage, the preparation contained predominantly Δ1–91RII with some minor contaminants including other peptide fragments. The protein was then combined with Cα as described for the holoenzyme, and the Δ1–91RC dimer was purified by the same Q2-FPLC procedure. Only R containing an intact pseudosubstrate site forms a stable complex. Following this purification, the Δ1–91RC dimer exhibited a single amino-terminal sequence for the first 10 amino acids by automatic Edman degradation, indicative of cleavage at the Phe91-Thr92 peptide bond of the murine RIIα sequence 92TRRVSVCAET … 2Murine Phe91 is equivalent to bovine Phe90. Note that no sequence would be obtained for the C subunit, because it was N-myristoylated. There was no evidence of any contaminating peptide fragments, nor of undigested R subunit. The Δ1–91RC dimer was in excess of 99% pure by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis with a molecular mass for the Δ1–91RII of the expected size of 35 kDa. The Δ1–91RC dimer exhibited a specific activity of 10.9 μmol of 32P incorporated/min/mg of protein in a Kemptide protein kinase assay plus cAMP, a without/with cAMP activity ratio of 0.1, a K a cAMP = 0.6 μm, and a molecular mass of 83 kDa by gel filtration. This same method of proteolysis was used to prepare the Δ1–90 fragment of bovine heart RII. Three PKA samples were prepared with average deuteration levels in the R subunit equal to 42, 68, and 71%. Deuteration levels were determined using the neutron contrast solvent match point for the complex (see “Results”). The Δ1–91RC dimer samples were obtained from the 42 and 68% deuterated R subunit preparations. Protein concentrations were routinely measured by the Bio-Rad assay, as standardized against quadruplicate amino acid analyses of PKA. Protein concentrations for scattering measurements were in the range of 0.65–0.96 mg/ml for the PKA holoenzyme and 1.2–2.7 mg/ml for the Δ1–91RC dimer. Samples were maintained in 10 mm MES (pH 6.8) with 10% (v/v) glycerol, 150–300 mm NaCl, 0.1 mm4-(2-aminoethyl)-benzenesulfonyl fluoride, and 15 mm2-mercaptoethanol. All scattering data were collected within 5 days of protein preparation to minimize possible time-dependent aggregation effects. Samples in high D2O concentrations were prepared immediately before neutron scattering measurements to minimize possible D2O-induced aggregation. X-ray scattering data were measured at Los Alamos using the instrument and data reduction procedures described by Heidorn and Trewhella (31Heidorn D.B. Trewhella J. Biochemistry. 1988; 27: 909-915Crossref PubMed Scopus (282) Google Scholar). Neutron scattering data were measured using the NG3 30-m SANS instrument at the National Institute of Standards Technology (32Hammouda B. Barker J.G. Kreuger S. Small Angle Scattering Manuals. National Institutes of Standards Technology, Gaithersburg, MD1996Google Scholar) and reduced as described previously (33Olah G.A. Rokop S.E. Wang C.-L.A. Blechner S.L. Trewhella J. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 8233-8239Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). Scattering data were measured as a function of scattering angle 2θ and reduced to I(Q)versus Q, where Q = 4πsinθ/λ is the momentum transfer of the scattered neutrons whose wavelength is λ. For the neutron scattering experiments, 5-Å neutrons were selected with a Δλ/λ of 30%, and two sample-to-detector distances were used (1.5 and 7.0 m) to give a measured Q range of 0.01–0.3 Å−1. For each reconstituted PKA sample, 2–5 neutron scattering data sets were collected with different solvent deuteration levels (0–94%). Samples with the highest solvent deuteration level were prepared by dialysis against buffer made up using 90% (v/v) D2O and 10% (v/v) glycerol-d 3. Intermediate solvent deuteration levels were obtained by mixing samples in the 94% deuterated solvent with those in all-protium solvent. Samples were stored on ice and maintained at 11 °C during data acquisition. Sample cells for scattering were 1-, 2-, and 4-mm path length quartz cuvettes for solvent deuteration levels of <50%, 50–70%, and >70%, respectively. The scattering of neutrons or x-rays from a homogeneous solution of monodisperse particles can be expressed as follows, I(Q)=∫‖[ρ(r)−ρs]exp[−i(Q·r)dr]‖2(Eq. 1) where the integration is taken over the volume of the particle, and angle brackets denote the average of all particle orientations. ρ(r) and ρs are the scattering densities for the protein and solvent, respectively, and their difference is the “contrast” of the protein with respect to the solvent. Scattering densities are calculated simply as the sum of the scattering amplitudes in a unit volume. The zero angle or forward scattering,I 0, is directly proportional to the square of the contrast and the square of the molecular weight of the scattering particle. When the average scattering density for a protein ρave equals ρs, the contrast is 0, and I 0 becomes 0, i.e. the protein is “solvent-matched.” X-rays are scattered by electrons, and hence, the scattering amplitudes increase monotonically with atomic number. Neutrons interact with atomic nuclei, and their scattering amplitudes vary randomly with atomic number and can be isotope-dependent. One of the largest differences in neutron scattering amplitudes is among the isotopes of hydrogen, protium (1H ≡ H), and deuterium (2H ≡ D), whose neutron scattering amplitudes differ both in magnitude and sign. Assuming internal scattering density fluctuations are negligible, the total scattering from a complex of C and deuterated R subunits can be written as follows, I(Q,ΔρC,ΔρR)=ΔρC2IC(Q)+ΔρC ΔρRICR(Q)+ΔρR2IR(Q)(Eq. 2) where ΔρC is the contrast between the C subunit and the solvent (ρC − ρs) and where ρC is the mean scattering density for C. A similar definition holds for ΔρR. By varying the protium/deuterium ratio in the solvent, a neutron contrast variation data set is obtained in which each scattering profile has the form of Equation 2 but with varying contrast factors. Since the contrast factors can be calculated from the chemical composition of the components, this resultant set of linear equations can be solved to give the basic scattering functionsI C(Q),I R(Q), and I CR(Q).I C(Q) and I R(Q) represent the scattering due to the C and R subunits within the complex, while the cross-termI CR(Q) contains information about the relative dispositions of the subunits. The inverse Fourier transformation of I(Q) gives the pair-distance distribution function, P(r), which is the probable frequency distribution of all vector lengths between scattering centers (atoms) within the particle.P(r) goes to 0 at the particle's maximum linear dimension, d max, and is easily interpreted in terms of the particle shape and domain structure. The forward scattering, I 0, and radius of gyration,R g, for the particle are calculated as the zeroth and second moments of P(r), respectively.P(r) calculations were done using the program GNOM (34Svergun D.I. Semenyuk A.V. Feigen L.A. Acta Crystallogr. 1988; A44: 244-250Crossref Scopus (275) Google Scholar). To model the scattering data, a Monte Carlo simulation program SASMODEL 3SASMODEL is written in C++, is available on request, and can run on most computer platforms with an adequate compiler. was developed. The program is designed to determine the shapes and relative dispositions of the macromolecular components (domains, subunits) by testing large numbers of models against scattering data. Each of the molecular components is described as a low resolution “object.” In the present implementation, these objects can be either ellipsoids or cylinders (which includes rods and discs). During the model search cycles, the size, position, and orientation parameters of each object to be optimized are generated by a random search or alternatively through a global minimization routine. 4The global minimization C-code is available from L. Ingeber on the World Wide Web athttp://www.ingeber.com/#ASA-CODE. The parameters can be constrained within a given range, and they can be correlated to each other. For example, two objects can be constrained to have the same dimension, to have surface contact with each other, or to have a certain symmetry with respect to a common symmetry center, axis, or plane. In order to test a model against the scattering data, a rapid Monte Carlo integration method (31Heidorn D.B. Trewhella J. Biochemistry. 1988; 27: 909-915Crossref PubMed Scopus (282) Google Scholar) is used to generate the modelP(r) function. Once the parameters for each object are generated, they are filled with random points, and P(r) is calculated by summing all pairwise combinations of these points. The correspondingI(Q) is calculated by Fourier transformation of P(r). P(r) and I(Q) functions are then compared with the experimental data by least-square methods. The points defining the models having the best least-square deviations from the experimental data are saved in Brookhaven Protein Data Bank format for ease of viewing. Neutron scattering data from one of the reconstituted PKA (R2C2) samples and from the corresponding Δ1–91RC dimer preparation, both with deuterated R, are shown in Fig. 1. Also shown are the x-ray scattering data for PKA and the Δ1–91RC dimer. The precise deuteration level in each R preparation was determined using the forward scattering values, I 0, at each solvent deuteration level for a given reconstituted sample. Fig. 2 shows plots of the square root of I 0 versus ρs for two of the PKA and two Δ1–91RC dimer samples made from three independently purified and reconstituted preparations. From these plots, the solvent match point is obtained for the complex,i.e. the value of ρs at whichI 0 = 0 and hence ρave = ρs. The average scattering densities ρave for PKA and the Δ1–91RC dimer are readily calculated from those of the individual R and C subunits, which are in turn calculated from their chemical and isotopic compositions. The only unknown is the deuteration level of the R subunit, which is then determined assuming a protein specific volume of 0.72 cm3/g for nondeuterated protein, and ∼45% of all exchangeable hydrogens of both the R and C subunits will be at equilibrium with the solvent hydrogens (27Olah G.A. Rokop S. Wang A.C. Blechner S.L. Trewhella J. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 8233-8239Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The calculated deuteration levels for the nonexchangeable hydrogen positions in the R subunit in each sample are given in Table I. Using these deuteration levels, contrast values were calculated for the R and C subunits (ΔρR and ΔρC in Equation 2) in each PKA and Δ1–91RC dimer sample for each solvent deuteration level. The scattering profiles measured at each contrast value for a given sample were then expressed in the form of Equation 2, and the linear equations were solved to yield the three basic scattering functions for PKA and for the Δ1–91RC dimer. The basic scattering functions so derived from the neutron scattering data are shown in Fig. 3, while their respectiveP(r) functions are shown in Fig. 4. Metabolic labeling of cells with [3H]dihydrosphingosine ([3H]DHS) allows us to follow the incorporation of this tracer into ceramides (Cer), inositol phosphoceramides (IPCs), and mannosylated IPCs and at the same time to assess the remodeling of glycosylphosphatidylinositol proteins during which preexisting anchor lipid moieties are replaced by [3H]Cer-containing anchors. The results indicate that the remodelases in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi use as their substrate Cers that are not generated by the breakdown of IPCs but are newly synthesized. Aureobasidin A, an inhibitor of the IPC synthase Aur1p completely blocks IPC biosynthesis at 0.5 μg/ml but does not block remodeling of glycosylphosphatidylinositol anchors even at concentrations up to 10 μg/ml. In addition, a synthetic Cer analogue,N-hexanoyl-[3H]DHS, is used as a substrate by Aur1p but not by the remodelases. Thus, remodeling is not mediated by Aur1p although remodeling presumably proceeds by an analogous reaction. Studies with secretion mutants deficient in COPII or COPI coat proteins show that all COPII mutants are unable to introduce [3H]Cer by the Golgi remodelase at the restrictive temperature. This suggests that Cer has to be transported by a COPII-dependent way from the endoplasmic reticulum to Golgi for Golgi remodeling to occur. Golgi remodeling is also not operating in the erd2 mutant and is significantly reduced in COPI mutants, suggesting a dependence of Golgi remodeling on retrotransport. In addition, a synthetic Cer analogue,N-hexanoyl-[3H]DHS, is used as a substrate by Aur1p but not by the remodelases. Thus, remodeling is not mediated by Aur1p although remodeling presumably proceeds by an analogous reaction. Studies with secretion mutants deficient in COPII or COPI coat proteins show that all COPII mutants are unable to introduce [3H]Cer by the Golgi remodelase at the restrictive temperature. This suggests that Cer has to be transported by a COPII-dependent way from the endoplasmic reticulum to Golgi for Golgi remodeling to occur. Golgi remodeling is also not operating in the erd2 mutant and is significantly reduced in COPI mutants, suggesting a dependence of Golgi remodeling on retrotransport. glycosylphosphatidylinositol aureobasidin A ceramide ceramide phosphate cycloheximide diacylglycerol dihydrosphingosine endoplasmic reticulum myo-inositol inositol phosphoceramide mannosylinositol phosphoceramide inositol phospho-MIPC myriocin phytosphingosine phospholipase C phospholipase D phosphatidylinositol wild type polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis carboxypeptidase Y. The lipid moieties of mature GPI1 anchors usually do not contain the DAG species found on the cells PI, although PI would appear as the natural starting point for the biosynthesis of the GPI (1McConville M.J. Ferguson M.A. Biochem. J. 1993; 294: 305-324Crossref PubMed Scopus (804) Google Scholar, 2Thomas J.R. Dwek R.A. Rademacher T.W. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 5414-5422Google Scholar). Studies in trypanosomes and in yeast strongly suggest that ordinary PIs indeed serve as the primary platform on which, by stepwise addition of sugars, GPIs are built but that the primary lipid moiety is remodeled later on, either shortly before transfer of the GPI to proteins (Trypanosoma brucei) or after this transfer (Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Trypanosoma cruzi) (3Masterson W.J. Raper J. Doering T.L. Hart G.W. Englund P.T. Cell. 1990; 62: 73-80Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar, 4Buxbaum L.U. Raper J. Opperdoes F.R. Englund P.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 30212-30220Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 5Sipos G. Puoti A. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 2789-2796Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar, 6Sipos G. Reggiori F. Vionnet C. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3494-3505Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar, 7Heise N. Raper J. Buxbaum L.U. Peranovich T.M.S. Cardoso de Almeida M.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 16877-16887Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar, 8Heise N. Cardoso de Almeida M.L. Ferguson M.A.J. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1995; 70: 71-84Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). Curiously, it appears that after remodeling, lipids continue to be exchanged even on mature GPI proteins, although this further lipid exchange replaces lipids by lipids of the same structure (9Reggiori F. Canivenc-Gansel E. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3506-3518Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar, 10Buxbaum L.U. Milne K.G. Werbovetz K.A. Englund P.T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 1178-1183Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). The situation in S. cerevisiae is peculiar since two different types of lipids can be found on GPI anchors as follows: Cer and DAG, both containing C26:0 or hydroxylated C26:0 (11Fankhauser C. Homans S.W. Thomas Oates J.E. McConville M.J. Desponds C. Conzelmann A. Ferguson M.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 26365-26374Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, all mature GPI proteins of yeast contain large lipid moieties with C26 fatty acids. The remodeling introducing Cer can be monitored by metabolic labeling experiments using tritiated DHS ([3H]DHS) (9Reggiori F. Canivenc-Gansel E. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3506-3518Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). When given to cells, this tracer is rapidly taken up and is incorporated into all sphingolipids as well as Cer-containing GPI proteins (Fig. 1). By labeling different secretion mutants with [3H]DHS or by using preincubations with cycloheximide (Chx), we found that GPI remodelase 2In this paper we will use the terms remodeling/remodelase to describe the event/enzyme that changes the primary DAG of the GPI anchor for a Cer. activity is present in both the ER and the Golgi (9Reggiori F. Canivenc-Gansel E. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3506-3518Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). Curiously, in temperature-sensitive secretion mutants such as sec12 orsec18, the incorporation of [3H]DHS into GPI proteins in the Golgi is completely blocked at 37 °C, whereas [3H]DHS continues to be incorporated into immature GPI proteins in the ER. This suggested that the substrate for the Golgi remodelase may not reach the Golgi, if the vesicular flow from the ER to the Golgi is interrupted. To allow for a more definitive interpretation of this result, we set out to identify the lipid substrate of the remodeling reaction. It seemed likely that lipid remodeling proceeds by some transesterification or transglycosylation since activated forms of Cer such as CDP-Cer have not been found in yeast although they exist in certain bacteria (12Schneider E.G. Kennedy E.P. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1976; 441: 294-301Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). A priori we had to consider that remodeling may occur by introduction of IPC, Cer-P, or Cer in exchange for PI, phosphatidic acid, or DAG, respectively. Introduction of IPC could be excluded since metabolic labeling of cells with [3H]Ins in the presence of the protein synthesis inhibitor Chx fails to label GPI proteins, whereas [3H]DHS is strongly incorporated under this condition (9Reggiori F. Canivenc-Gansel E. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3506-3518Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). We could, however, not exclude that remodelases use IPC as a substrate from which to take Cer-P or Cer for transesterification. This hypothesis even seemed attractive since, when the vesicular traffic from ER to Golgi is blocked in temperature-sensitive COPII mutants, the main IPC (IPC/C) continues to be made in the ER, but mannosylation of IPC/C to MIPC in the Golgi is abolished indicating that IPC is neither transported to the Golgi nor synthesized in the Golgi under these conditions (9Reggiori F. Canivenc-Gansel E. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3506-3518Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar, 13Puoti A. Desponds C. Conzelmann A. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 113: 515-525Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar, 14Abeijon C. Yanagisawa K. Mandon E.C. Hausler A. Moremen K. Hirschberg C.B. Robbins P.W. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 122: 307-323Crossref PubMed Scopus (159) Google Scholar). Thus, this lack of transport of IPC to the Golgi could explain the lack of GPI remodeling in the Golgi in COPII mutants. Here we present evidence in favor of Cer rather than Cer-P as a remodelase substrate, and we establish that this Cer substrate is newly synthesized and is not taken from IPC or other more complex sphingolipids. By using aureobasidin A (AbA), a recently identified inhibitor of IPC biosynthesis (15Nagiec M.M. Nagiec E.E. Baltisberger J.A. Wells G.B. Lester R.L. Dickson R.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 9809-9817Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (328) Google Scholar), we can demonstrate that Golgi remodeling of GPI proteins is occurring normally even if IPC biosynthesis is blocked. Our data lend support to the hypothesis that it is newly synthesized Cer that is used for remodeling. We further present evidence against the possibility that the Aur1p and Ipt1p contain remodelase activity. Moreover, using secretion and retrieval mutants, we evaluate the necessity of COPI- and COPII-dependent vesicle flow for the transfer of Cer onto GPI proteins in the Golgi. The gels were then processed for fluorography. When preparing cell extracts for protein analysis, the organic solvent extracts were saved, pooled, and dried. Where indicated, lipids were subjected to mild base treatment using NaOH (21Puoti A. Desponds C. Fankhauser C. Conzelmann A. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 21051-21059Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Lipids were desalted by partitioning between n-butyl alcohol and water followed by back extraction of the butanol phase with water (19Krakow J.L. Hereld D. Bangs J.D. Hart G.W. Englund P.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 12147-12153Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The desalted lipids were analyzed by ascending TLC using 0.2-mm thick silica gel plates with solvent system 1 (chloroform, methanol, 2 mNH4OH (40:10:1)), solvent system 2 (chloroform, methanol, 0.25% KCl (55:45:10)), or solvent system 3 (chloroform, methanol, 2m acetic acid (18:10:2)). Radioactivity was quantified by radioscanning using a Berthold radioscanner (22Benghezal M. Lipke P.N. Conzelmann A. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 130: 1333-1344Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar). Results were calculated from the scans by summing up the radioactivity of all lipid peaks including [3H]DHS and by dividing the radioactivity in any given lipid by this sum. Lipids were scraped and eluted from the TLC with methanol as described (17Reggiori, F., Canivenc-Gansel, E., and Conzelmann, A. (1998)Methods Mol. Biol., in pressGoogle Scholar). The extract was pooled and dried. Lipids were desalted by partitioning betweenn-butyl alcohol and water followed by a back extraction of the butanol phase with water (19Krakow J.L. Hereld D. Bangs J.D. Hart G.W. Englund P.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 12147-12153Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Aliquots were then subjected to strong acid hydrolysis (23Conzelmann A. Fankhauser C. Puoti A. Desponds C. Cell Biol. Int. Rep. 1991; 15: 863-873Crossref PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar) or treated with PI-PLC for 16 h (24Puoti A. Conzelmann A. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 7215-7224Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). After treatments, lipids were desalted with partitioning betweenn-butyl alcohol and water. GPI peptides were purified from 15A 600 of cells and treated with PI-PLC (0.05 units) as described (9Reggiori F. Canivenc-Gansel E. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3506-3518Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar, 17Reggiori, F., Canivenc-Gansel, E., and Conzelmann, A. (1998)Methods Mol. Biol., in pressGoogle Scholar). GPI-PLD treatment was performed by resuspending the GPI peptides in 100 μl of PI-PLD buffer II (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 4.5, 10 mm NaCl, 2.6 mm CaCl2, 20% propanol) and adding 0.5 units of GPI-PLD (17Reggiori, F., Canivenc-Gansel, E., and Conzelmann, A. (1998)Methods Mol. Biol., in pressGoogle Scholar). The samples were incubated overnight at 37 °C. P-Cer obtained by GPI-PLD was dephosphorylated to Cer by alkaline phosphatase treatment (17Reggiori, F., Canivenc-Gansel, E., and Conzelmann, A. (1998)Methods Mol. Biol., in pressGoogle Scholar). Previous studies have revealed that the Cer moieties introduced into GPI anchors by remodeling are not representative of the cell-free Cers. In particular, if secretion is blocked in sec18, the prevalent PHS-C26OH is used to make IPC/C, whereas cells incorporate into GPI anchors a more hydrophobic, PHS-containing lipid, probably PHS-C26 (9Reggiori F. Canivenc-Gansel E. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3506-3518Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). Since both of these reactions occur in the ER, this discrepancy made us suspicious that the remodelases may draw on Cers present in form of Cer-P or else on IPCs. To evaluate the possibility of Cer-P being the substrate for remodeling reactions, we set out to see if cells contain a pool of free Cer-P. Standards were prepared from [3H]DHS-labeled GPI proteins using phospholipases. PI-PLC treatment of anchor peptides generated Cers α, β, and γ corresponding to DHS-C26, PHS-C26, and PHS-C26OH (Fig. 2, lane 2), the γCer only being found on GPI proteins having reached the Golgi (6Sipos G. Reggiori F. Vionnet C. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3494-3505Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar, 9Reggiori F. Canivenc-Gansel E. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3506-3518Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). GPI-PLD treatment of anchor peptides generated three more polar lipids representing phosphorylated forms of Cers α, β, and γ (Fig. 2,lane 7). They were resistant to mild alkaline hydrolysis and could be converted to Cers α, β, and γ by phosphatase treatment (not shown). Lipid extracts from wild type or heat-shockedsec18 cells did contain lipids migrating close to these Cer-P standards, but they were not resistant to alkaline hydrolysis and hence are not Cer-Ps (Fig. 2, lanes 3–6). In particular, after mild base hydrolysis, the region corresponding to βCer-P, which is derived from the most abundant anchor species, was completely empty. Any isolated band containing >0.03% of the radioactivity spotted in each lane (5 μCi/1 cm) is detected by the radioscanner. In comparison, the free Cer (PHS-C26OH) comigrating with γCer accounts for 7.8% (wt) and 16.8% (sec18) of the total lipid extract. Thus, Cer-P, if present at all, is at least 260- or 560-fold less abundant than the Cer PHS-C26OH. This makes it rather unlikely that free Cer-Ps would serve as substrates for GPI remodeling reactions. We also wanted to rule out the possibility that in a first step free [3H]DHS or [3H]PHS is introduced into GPI anchors, in exchange for diacylglycerol, and that the long chain base is N-acylated only subsequently. For this we used australifungin, a recently described antifungal drug that blocks the sphinganineN-acyltransferase thus blocking the conversion of DHS to Cer (25Mandala S.M. Thornton R.A. Frommer B.R. Curotto J.E. Rozdilsky W. Kurtz M.B. Giacobbe R.A. Bills G.F. Cabello M.A. Martin I. Pelaez F. Harris G.H. J. Antibiot. (Tokyo). 1995; 48: 349-356Crossref PubMed Scopus (132) Google Scholar). When present at 0.5 μg/ml, australifungin completely blocked the incorporation of [3H]DHS into Cer and IPCs as expected. At the same time it also completely abrogated incorporation of [3H]DHS into GPI proteins (not shown). This argues in favor of the idea that [3H]DHS has first to be converted to [3H]Cer before being incorporated into GPI anchors. Aureobasidin A is a potent inhibitor of the IPC synthase Aur1p, an essential enzyme transferring Ins-P from PI to Cer, thus forming IPC (15Nagiec M.M. Nagiec E.E. Baltisberger J.A. Wells G.B. Lester R.L. Dickson R.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 9809-9817Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (328) Google Scholar). The main toxicity of AbA is due to its effect on Aur1p since point mutations in AUR1 render cells resistant to AbA (15Nagiec M.M. Nagiec E.E. Baltisberger J.A. Wells G.B. Lester R.L. Dickson R.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 9809-9817Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (328) Google Scholar, 26Hashida-Okado T. Ogawa A. Endo M. Yasumoto R. Takesako K. Kato I. Mol. Gen. Genet. 1996; 251: 236-244PubMed Google Scholar). The subcellular localization of Aur1p has not been reported, but it is believed to reside in the ER since in temperature-sensitive COPII mutants the main IPC (IPC/C) continues to be made when the vesicular traffic from ER to Golgi is blocked, whereas mannosylation of IPC/C to MIPC in the Golgi is blocked indicating that IPC is neither transported to the Golgi nor synthesized in the Golgi under these conditions (9Reggiori F. Canivenc-Gansel E. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3506-3518Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar, 13Puoti A. Desponds C. Conzelmann A. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 113: 515-525Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar, 14Abeijon C. Yanagisawa K. Mandon E.C. Hausler A. Moremen K. Hirschberg C.B. Robbins P.W. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 122: 307-323Crossref PubMed Scopus (159) Google Scholar). To monitor the effect of AbA on the remodeling of GPI anchors, we labeled cells with [3H]Ins and [3H]DHS which both can be used to selectively label GPI proteins. AbA did not affect the incorporation of [3H]Ins and [3H]DHS into proteins (Fig. 3) at a concentration at which incorporation into sphingolipids was completely blocked (not shown). We found that for a complete inhibition of IPC biosynthesis, it was necessary to have 0.2 μg/ml (= 0.17 μm) AbA in the labeling medium, the same concentration as is required to achieve complete growth arrest. These experiments indicate that GPI remodeling can occur in the absence of IPC biosynthesis and argue against the possibility that [3H]DHS is first incorporated into IPC in order to become integrated into a GPI anchor. We wanted to know if both, ER and Golgi remodelase activities are independent of AUR1, and we therefore tested AbA in the previously established experimental settings in which only ER or only Golgi activity is assayed (9Reggiori F. Canivenc-Gansel E. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3506-3518Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). ER activity can be measured in the secretion mutant sec18, which at 37 °C effectively blocks incorporation of [3H]DHS into mature-sized GPI proteins in the Golgi. As can be seen in Fig. 4 A, at a concentration of AbA which completely blocks the biosynthesis of IPCs and of M(IP)2C, the incorporation of [3H]DHS into immature GPI proteins is somewhat reduced but so is the incorporation of [3H]Ins, the latter being a reflection of the rates of GPI protein synthesis and turnover but not remodeling. The result suggests that AbA has no effect on the efficiency of remodeling of GPI proteins in the ER. The conditions used in Fig. 4 A do not exclude the possibility that some of the remodeling activity is due to newly made Golgi remodelase in transit to the Golgi, which was trapped in the ER by the secretion block. To eliminate this possibility we used another preincubation protocol allowing us to specifically measure the autochthonous ER remodelase activity as detailed in Fig. 4 B. Fig. 4 B shows that under these conditions the incorporation of [3H]DHS into proteins is not reduced by AbA, whereas incorporation of [3H]DHS into IPC/B, IPC/C, IPC/D, and M(IP)2C is completely blocked. The incorporation of [3H]DHS into IPC/D and M(IP)2C is blocked even in the absence of AbA as a result of the secretion block, as mentioned above (9Reggiori F. Canivenc-Gansel E. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3506-3518Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). To evaluate the effect of AbA on the Golgi remodelase, cells were pretreated with Chx, allowing GPI proteins to be exported out of the ER before the label was added (9Reggiori F. Canivenc-Gansel E. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3506-3518Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 5, with this protocol, AbA diminishes the labeling of mature-sized proteins with [3H]DHS somewhat, whereas the biosynthesis of sphingolipids is completely blocked. Thus, both ER and Golgi remodelases are able to incorporate [3H]DHS even if IPC biosynthesis is completely blocked. Cers of GPI proteins seem to get exchanged for Cers (9Reggiori F. Canivenc-Gansel E. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3506-3518Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar), but this conservative lipid exchange does not seem to occur on sphingolipids since no labeling of IPC, MIPC, or M(IP)2C is observed in wt cells in the presence of AbA. This, however, does not rule out the possibility of such an exchange being mediated by Aur1p. Cer has been found to be toxic to cells, and its toxicity was considered to be the reason for the lack of success in early attempts to generate mutants in IPC biosynthesis (15Nagiec M.M. Nagiec E.E. Baltisberger J.A. Wells G.B. Lester R.L. Dickson R.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 9809-9817Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (328) Google Scholar, 27Nickels J.T. Broach J.R. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 382-394Crossref PubMed Scopus (176) Google Scholar, 28Fishbein J.D. Dobrowsky R.T. Bielawska A. Garrett S. Hannun Y.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 9255-9261Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Our results document, however, that AbA does not compromise the synthesis of GPI proteins nor their remodeling for the duration of the experiment (3 h), although it can be expected that the endogenously produced Cer reaches very high levels under these conditions (15Nagiec M.M. Nagiec E.E. Baltisberger J.A. Wells G.B. Lester R.L. Dickson R.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 9809-9817Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (328) Google Scholar). It should be noted that the accumulation of [3H]PHS-C26OH does not reflect the increase in cold Cer. In the presence of AbA, [3H]PHS-C26OH reaches only about 3-fold higher levels than in the absence of the inhibitor (Fig. 3). This elevation is moderate since even in the absence of AbA no more than 20–25% of [3H]DHS added to cells gets incorporated into sphingolipids, whereas the rest is degraded and incorporated into other types of phospholipids. Collectively the results described so far support the idea that newly synthesized Cer is the substrate for the remodeling of GPI anchors in yeast and that the remodelases exchange DAG for Cer. This type of transesterification reaction is analogous to the biosynthesis of IPC by Aur1p, an enzyme replacing the DAG moiety of PI by a Cer. The following experiments were performed to see if Aur1p is the remodelase of GPI anchors. (i) As shown in Fig. 6, AbA does not interfere with GPI remodeling even at elevated concentrations (10 μg/ml). (ii) When cells were incubated with chemically acylated [3H]DHS (N-acetylated orN-hexanoylated), we did not find any incorporation of these short chain Cers into GPI proteins although they were efficiently incorporated into IPC and M(IP)2C (Fig. 7, A and B; not shown). Even when purifying large amounts of glycoproteins over concanavalin A-Sepharose and preparing anchor peptides in the same way as done in Fig. 9 C, we could not find any traces of radioactivity in anchor peptides from DHS-C2- or DHS-C6-labeled cells. (iii) As mentioned, if secretion is blocked in sec18, Aur1p uses the prevalent PHS-C26OH to make IPC/C, whereas cells incorporate into GPI anchors a more hydrophobic, PHS-containing lipid, probably PHS-C26 (9Reggiori F. Canivenc-Gansel E. Conzelmann A. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 3506-3518Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). These data suggest that the remodelase has a different substrate specificity than Aur1p. We also tested if theAUR1 homologue IPT1 is involved in Golgi remodeling. IPT1 has been shown to be necessary for the transfer of inositol phosphate from PI onto MIPC in order to make M(IP)2C, a reaction that is supposed to occur in the Golgi (13Puoti A. Desponds C. Conzelmann A. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 113: 515-525Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar, 29Dickson R.C. Nagiec E.E. Wells G.B. Nagiec M.M. Lester R.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 29620-29625Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar). We find that the deletion of IPT1 has no influence on Golgi remodelase (Fig. 7 D) and also has no effect on the incorporation of [3H]DHS into proteins when all remodelases are measured simultaneously (not shown). An ∼37-kDa cytoplasmic protein is rapidly tyrosine-phosphorylated in the response of mouse BAC1.2F5 macrophages to colony stimulating factor-1 (CSF-1). pp37 was purified from the cytosolic fraction by anti-Tyr(P) affinity chromatography, size exclusion chromatography, and C<sub>4</sub> reverse phase high pressure liquid chromatography. The sequences of four peptides derived from the purified protein matched portions of an expressed sequence tag (EST) sequence, and the EST clone was used to obtain cDNA clones encoding the pp37 protein, which shares sequence similarity with the PST PIP (proline, serine,threonine phosphatase interactingprotein)/CDC15 family of protein-tyrosine phosphatase substrates. pp37 is predicted to contain a Fes/CIP4 homology (FCH) domain and an actin-binding domain-like sequence. It is expressed selectively in macrophages, macrophage cell lines, and at low levels in macrophage-containing tissues. pp37 is predominantly found in the cytosol, where it is associated with actin. However, ∼4% resides in the membrane fraction, and the trace amount in the cytoskeletal fraction is increased by CSF-1 stimulation. Termedmacrophage actin-associated tyrosine-phosphorylated protein (MAYP), p37 is the major F-actin-associated protein that is tyrosine-phosphorylated in macrophages and is likely to play a role in regulating the CSF-1-induced reorganization of the actin cytoskeleton.

Voltage-dependent anion channels (VDACs) are pore-forming proteins found in the outer mitochondrial membrane of all eucaryotes. VDACs are the major pathway for metabolites through the outer mitochondrial membrane and, in mammals, bind several cytosolic carbohydrate kinases. Whereas yeast contain a single VDAC (YVDAC), to date three isoforms have been described in the mouse that constitute a gene family. We have observed an additional isoform of VDAC3 that appears to be generated via the tissue-specific alternative splicing of a 3-base exon (ATG). The exon is predicted to introduce a methionine 39 amino acids downstream of the amino terminus of the polypeptide. Between exons 3 and 4 is an intronic sequence that potentially encodes the exon, with flanking splice enhancer elements. Expression of this alternative form in the mouse is limited to brain, heart, and skeletal muscle. Complementation of YVDAC-deficient yeast by the two isoforms and with other sequence variants of VDAC3 suggests this residue is an important modulator of VDAC3 function. In transfected mammalian cells both isoforms localize to mitochondria. A similar variant is present in humans. Complementation of YVDAC-deficient yeast by the two isoforms and with other sequence variants of VDAC3 suggests this residue is an important modulator of VDAC3 function. In transfected mammalian cells both isoforms localize to mitochondria.
